OWEN OKAYS AD HOC;
DECISION AWAITED
BY J. D. CONSIDINE

dcademic Council
Quiet and Reluctant
Quiet acceptance and
reluctance to comment
characterized the mood of the
Academic Council in the
aftermath of Dean Owen's
decision to form an ad hoc
committee. They acknowledged
that .the Dean was well within his
prerogatives in appointing an ad
hoc committee to study Dr.
Richard Pfeffer's qualifications
for tenure.
"If you look literally at his
rights and prerogatives, it was
Within the Dean's rights to take
that action," said Dr. William H.
Huggens of the Electrical
Engineering Department. "I
thought that (the decision) was
Perfectly within his purview,"
added Dr. Doris Entwisle of
Social Relations.
None of the Council members
criticized Dean Owen's decision.
Dr. Maurice Bessman of the
Biology Department commented,
"He was at all of the discussions
and meetings in both the spring
and the fall. In his judgement, it
Was in the best interests of the
University to form a committee."
Dr. Brown Murr of the Chemistry
Department said, "Dean Owen is
a thoughtful and serious person. I
Was not surprised at all by the
decision."
Some faculty members
Previously had expressed fear

that Dean Owen's action might
set a harmful precedent for the
future. Dr. Entwisle dismissed
this concern. "Each case is
unique and has many different
facets. Since it was handled
entirely within the rules, I don't
think it will set a bad precedent."
Dr. Richard E. Flathman of the
Political Science Department
declined comment on the
question of precedent because he
felt he was not sufficiently
informed concerning the "basis
of the decision." However, he
noted that "there is a firm
tradition of the University that
says the faculty are the primary
body to make decisions regarding
personnel."
According to Dr. Flathman,
there was more communication
between Council members and
other faculty members
concerning the issue before,.
Wednesday's Council vote.
"Considering the amount of
general interest," he said, "I
would say it was surprising how
little communication there was
(among Council members)." Dr.
Murr commented that there was
a considerable amount of
"politicking" prior to the vote.
"T. had people in my office all
day trying to influence me," he
said.
—Robert Riggs

On Friday afternoon, Dr.
George Owen, Dean of the
Faculty of Arts and Sciences
announced to the Academic
Council that he had decided to
form an ad hoc committee to
consider tenure for Associate
Professor Richard M. Pfeffer.
According to University sources,
however, the decision was not
intended to override the decision
of the Academic Council; rather,
it was delivered in the interest of
fairness, and in consideration of
the divided opinion of the
Council.
The Academic Council, which
met Wednesday night, serves in
an advisory capacity to the
President of the University.
Because of a general policy of
confidentiality concerning
Council matters, the exact vote
of the Council is unknown.
Although there had been
reports that University President
Steven Muller, chairman of the
Council, had voted in the case,
such reports were termed
fictitious by University officials.
According to reliable sources, the
Academic Council vote was tied,
and, as stated in Robert's Rules
of Order ,"When there is a tie
vote, the motion fails."
There also had been reports

that both Dean Owen and Dean
of Undergraduate Studies
Sigmund Suskind had threatened
to resign over the Academic
Council's decision. These reports
were denied in the Baltimore Sun
on Saturday.
According to reliable
Administration sources, the bulk
pf the Administration's action
was on the part of President
Muller. Dr. Muller, who spent
Thursday in Detroit, met with
the Deans Friday morning, when
it was decided to go ahead with
the ad hoc committee. Although
the decision to form the
committee was functionally that
of Dean Owen, the action was
taken, according to an official
statement, ''...with the
knowledge and approval of the
President."
The ad hoc committee, which
will consist of three faculty
members, has already been
selected, although the identities
of the committee members are
confidential. "Traditionally,"
Dean Owen said,"they are secret.
The selection of committee
'members was very careful, and
Dean Owen said, "I think the
members of the committee will
be very fair. But they must be
kept secret."
Dr. Pfeffer, at the center of
idle controversy, was both

cheerful and relieved by the
results of his case so far. "It has
really been a very severe, very
intense struggle, " Dr. Pfeffer
said. "It has been an ordeal, but
in many ways, I think it has been
healthy for all of us."
Rather than appear bitter, Dr.
Pfeffer was very positive in his
remarks. Although he conceded
that, "the opposition has been
fierce, ruthless, and, at times,
unethical," he had nothing but
compliments for his supporters.
"The people who have supported
me, both students and faculty,
have reason to be proud of what
we've accomplished."
Acknowledging that the case
was far from closed, Dr. Pfeffer
remarked that there was not a
great deal students could do to
aid his cause at the moment,
although the greater issue of
student input into such decisions
still deserves attention.
Nonetheless, Dr. Pfeffer
concluded his statement noting
that, "After all, half the
Academic Council did stand up
for my getting a fair hearing, and
that should not be lost sight of."
As yet, one could only guess
when the ad hoc,committee will •
make its recommendation. "It
will be deliberate," said Dean
Owen of the committee. "But
they all are, if they're right."

And now a
word from
your President s
The question of fairness for Associate Professor Richard Pfeffer has been a matter of
salient concern to the Hopkins community since early Spring. From that time forward.
expression of student outrage has developed a nature and intensity unknown at
Hopkins for a decade or more; forms that fall within the bounds of acceptable social
protest. And it remained unclear whether that outcry -- as manifested in countless
discussions, petitions, letters, editorials, and a definitive undergraduate referendum -would be heeded. The events of last week, culminating in the authorization of an ad
hoc review of Dr. Pfeffer's candidacy for tenure, have proven that the student
sentiment at the University have not gone unnoticed.
We of the Student Council applaud President Muller's approval of the ad hoc
committee investigation, and fervently hope that the advent of a new responsiveness
to student opinion, at Hopkins and throughout academia, has begun.
David Chcsanow, President

The New Political Caucus commends the decision,'
announced Friday, November 11th, to appoint an ad hoc
committee to review Dr. Pfeffer's candidacy for tenure.
We continue to feel that an ad hoc committee is the only
way to fairly and justly examine Dr. Pfeffer's scholarship
in light of the extreme controversy surrounding this entire
issue. Because the ad hoc committee has been approved
the rally which had been planned for Tuesday, November
15th is cancelled. We would, however, like to thank
everyone who spent so much time and effort working
with us for fairness, including: the Student Council, the
many faculty members and members of the
administration who offered advice and support, the
Baltimore city newspapers and television stations, the
City Squeeze, the News-Letter, the Office of the
Chaplain, the many graduate students who wrote letters
and signed petitions, and all of the undergraduates who
participated in the student referendum. The interest and
concern exhibited by the student body in the past few
weeks demonstrates that not only are Hopkins students
not as apathetic as we are sometimes portrayed, but that
we are capable of expressing our opinion in a mature,
intelligent, but nevertheless, forceful manner.
Though last Friday's News-letter's editorial described
the campus as "bitterly divided" we would strongly assert
that the lines of division are not clearly or easily defined.
It is definitely not a case of students against faculty or
faculty against administration, though some might
mistakenly try to. describe it in those terms. Instead, Dr.
Pfeffer's appeal and the discussions about it have provided
all of us with the opportunity to question and decide for
ourselves and our university what abstract concepts like
academic freedom and good scholarship mean in real'

situations. In the past few months many people have
become familiar with the mechanics of getting tenure at
Hopkins. Now is a very good time to question that system
and to ask whether something might be done to insure
due process and impartial evaluations in every tenure
decision, not just those approved by a particular
department or those that attract publicity. As students
who have suffered through more than one disorganized or
badly communicated lecture we would do well to go one
step further and ask whether teaching ought to be
considered much more seriously in these tenure decisions
in the future. It is our - position that there ought to be
some provisions within this university to insure the
quality of undergraduate teaching. After all aren't we here
to get an education? Presumably we are paying tuition to
receive something which we could not get staying at home
and reading the books written by various faculty
members.
Hopefully the decision to appoint an ad hoc committee
marks the beginning of a new consciousness at Hopkins. A
consciousness which in part says that it is about time
people took an interest in what is going on in this
university and challenged the laws of inertia at work to
maintain the status quo. Hopefully this action also marks
movement towards a final decision which will end the
long and undoubtedly painful ordeal of Dr. Pfeffer and
his family. The New Political Caucus remains confident of
Dr. Pfeffer's superb teaching ability and of his value to
the entire university community, and we await the reports
on his scholarship compiled by an unbiased ad hoc
committee.
The New Political Caucus
